item.title: Today: Best of Today
item.description:
With the Jubilee celebrations focussing on St Paul's Cathedral today, spare a thought for Dr Alex Kumar, who is probably the remotest British subject to be marking the Queen's 60 year reign. He is in Antarctica, at Concordia station in the world's largest desert, there with a team of scientists in complete isolation.
He's the doctor, the only Briton in a European Space Agency project to look at human physiology and psychology in conditions as close to another planet as you will find on earth. He tells Evan Davis about the weather there and his plans to celebrate the Queen's Golden Jubilee.

item.title: Today: Best of Today
item.description:
Baroness Warsi is to be investigated over whether she broke the ministerial code by taking a business partner on an official visit to Pakistan.
David Cameron has asked Sir Alex Allan, his independent adviser on ministerial interests, to look into the matter after she apologised for failing to disclose her business relationship with Abid Hussain.

item.title: Today: Business news with Lesley Curwen
item.description: Fears are increasing over the finances of Cyprus. Cyprus, supposedly the birthplace of Aphrodite, the goddess of love, is a sun-baked country of only around a million people. On Friday the president, Demetris Christofias said that asking for a bailout from Europe was not off the table. Comments which were then echoed by the finance minister the next day. Cyprus is especially vulnerable to a Greek exit from the Euro and its banking sector has a huge exposure to Greece.

item.title: Today: Jubilee "gush and gargle"
item.description: The Queen's Diamond Jubilee has been celebrated throughout the country to widespread, although not universal, acclaim. Journalist and broadcaster Matthew Parris delivers his own hyperbole-free tribute to the Queen. Also, the former Conservative MP and broadcaster, Gyles Brandreth and the Guardian's satirical cartoonist Steve Bell go head to head on whether the Jubilee is a genuine expression of love for the monarch, or a hollow exercise in public sycophancy.
